item.title: LIBOR pains
item.description: For decades, banks used one rate to help set all other rates: LIBOR. After it came out that it'd been rigged, regulators said: no more. Now it's a race â€” and a road trip â€” to find an alternative. | Subscribe to our weekly newsletter here.

item.title: Mayim Bialik on the Surprising Risks of Academia and Stability of Show Biz (People I (Mostly) Admire, Ep. 2 Replay)
item.description: This new Jeopardy! host is best known for playing neurobiologist Amy Farrah Fowler on The Big Bang Theory, but she has a rich life outside of her acting career too, as a teacher, mother â€” and a real-life neuroscientist. Steve learns more about this one-time academic and Hollywood non-conformist, who is both very similar to him and also quite his opposite.
item.author: radio@freakonomics.com (Freakonomics Radio + Stitcher)

item.title: Inside China's High-Tech Penal Colony with Darren Byler
item.description: Since 2017, a high-tech form of colonization has been rapidly growing in Xinjiang, China. As many as 1.5 million Muslim Uyghurs have vanished into high-security camps and factories. The Chinese regime describes these sites as â€œvocational education and training centersâ€ that are utilized to counter terrorism. But what actually goes on inside of these internment camps? Thatâ€™s the subject of Darren Bylerâ€™s new book, â€œIn The Camps: Chinaâ€™s High-Tech Penal Colony.â€ In it, Byler draws on a decade of research on the region. He joins to discuss his findings and the role of various forms of technology including facial recognition, smartphones and apps like WeChat, in government surveillance.
item.author: think@nbcuni.com (Darren Byler, Chris Hayes)

item.title: Office Space
item.description: Kasra Farahani has done concept art on a lot of big sci-fi fantasy films, and this year he took on his biggest job yet as the production designer for the Disney+ series Loki. Kasraâ€™s sets became fan favorites, especially the way he depicted the sprawling intergalactic bureaucracy of the Time Variance Authority, or TVA. I talk with Kasra about how he got started in the industry, what design principles he learned working with Tim Burtonâ€™s go-to designer Bo Welch, why retro technology, especially from the 1970s, makes sense in sci-fi fantasy offices, and what those imaginary offices have to say about our workplaces in the real world. This episode is sponsored by Inked Gaming and BetterHelp. Our ad partner is Multitude. If youâ€™re interested in advertising on Imaginary Worlds, you can contact them here. item.content:encoded:
Kasra Farahani has done concept art on a lot of big sci-fi fantasy films, and this year he took on his biggest job yet as the production designer for the Disney+ series Loki. Kasraâ€™s sets became fan favorites, especially the way he depicted the sprawling intergalactic bureaucracy of the Time Variance Authority, or TVA. I talk with Kasra about how he got started in the industry, what design principles he learned working with Tim Burtonâ€™s go-to designer Bo Welch, why retro technology, especially from the 1970s, makes sense in sci-fi fantasy offices, and what those imaginary offices have to say about our workplaces in the real world.

This episode is sponsored by Inked Gaming and BetterHelp. Our ad partner is Multitude. If youâ€™re interested in advertising on Imaginary Worlds, you can contact them here.
